article.headline: Northern Arizona 75, Arizona State 71
article.story: TEMPE, Ariz. (AP) -- For weeks, Herb Sendek has been telling anyone who would listen that it's going to take a massive effort to revive the Arizona State basketball program. The Sun Devils provided plenty of evidence in a stunning 75-71 loss to Northern Arizona here Monday night, spoiling Sendek's debut in front of an announced crowd of 10,267. "It's not going to happen overnight," Sendek said. "I don't think anybody thought it was going to. Experiences like this will only serve to strengthen our resolve and increase our determination, I assure you." Tyrone Bazy scored 21 points and Stephen Sir and Josh Wilson added 12 points apiece as NAU beat ASU for the first time since 1998. "I'm so happy for our guys," NAU coach Mike Adras said. "It's going to make the drive up the hill (to Flagstaff) that much sweeter." ASU had won 16 straight home openers. Its last home-opening loss was in 1989, when the Sun Devils lost to Brigham Young in Bill Frieder's first season as head coach. Jerren Shipp led ASU with 23 points, the most by a Sun Devil freshman in his first game, and freshman Christian Polk added 22. "I guess the good news and the bad news is the freshmen led the way," Sendek said. The Lumberjacks led 69-63 when Shipp hit a 3-pointer from the top of the key with 38 seconds to go. But Bazy hit four free throws and Ruben Boykin added two in the final 30 seconds to clinch the win for NAU. Along with the two freshmen, Sendek started three sophomores -- point guard Antwi Atuahene, forward Jeff Pendergraph and forward Sylvester Seay. The young Sun Devils struggled against an experienced Lumberjack team that started three seniors and a junior. NAU is the defending Big Sky Conference regular-season champions. Arizona State led 14-5 after seven minutes, but NAU responded with a 9-0 run to tie the game at 14-14 midway through the first half. The Lumberjacks took a 26-25 lead on Ryan McCurdy's fastbreak dunk with six minutes to go in the first half. NAU closed the first half on a 22-10 run to take a 39-33 lead into intermission. The Sun Devils hit six of their first eight shots from the floor but then went cold. They made only nine of their next 26 shots to end the first half. With so little experience, ASU's offense struggled to find a rhythm. Most of its offense was generated by Polk. The 6-foot-3 freshman from nearby Glendale, had nine shots in the first 8:32 -- as many as the rest of the Devils combined. At halftime, Polk led all scorers with 16 points on 8-of-15 shots from the floor. He missed his next eight shots and did not score another point until 2:25 left in the game. Polk went 2-for-11 from three-point range. ASU hit only 10-of-36 from beyond the arc.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
